item.title: Your Point to Point Ethernet Connection
item.description: Businesses with multiple locations often need to share data, traditionally relying on T1 lines for connectivity. While multiple T1 lines can increase bandwidth, this approach might not be the most cost-effective solution, especially in metropolitan areas. Point-to-point Ethernet offers a compelling alternative, often at a lower cost per Mbps, particularly for higher bandwidth needs. Ethernet streamlines data transmission by maintaining its format throughout the network, potentially allowing locations to function as a single bridged LAN.

item.title: Cheaper Connections To The Cloud
item.description: Businesses are often quick to celebrate the cost savings of cloud services compared to maintaining their own data centers. However, there’s a hidden cost that often catches them off guard: cloud connectivity. The current cost of bandwidth depends on a company’s blend of LAN, MAN, and WAN traffic. Businesses with data centers located in the same building as their employees usually find most of their application traffic stays on the LAN.

item.title: Ethernet Services over Copper
item.description: Connecting networks logically often involves Ethernet, a technology that has recently expanded its reach beyond local boundaries. Ethernet over Copper (EoC) connections are increasing in availability and often come at a lower cost compared to other options. EoC enables standard Ethernet services to be delivered through existing copper telephone wiring. Unlike typical Cat 5E or Cat 6 wiring, EoC is compatible with older copper infrastructure not initially intended for Ethernet.

item.title: 1,000,000 Miles of Metro Ethernet Fiber And Growing
item.description: Don’t assume Metro Ethernet is a small, insignificant service. XO Communications alone has a vast network of metro fiber, connecting thousands of buildings. And that’s just one provider, not even counting Ethernet over Copper options. Metro Ethernet and its long-distance counterpart, Carrier Ethernet, are the future of telecommunications. The world is shifting from traditional circuit-based communication to packet-based IP networks. While your current internet might be a T1 line, your data likely transitions to an IP-based backbone at your provider’s location.

item.title: Bandwidth To Support Branch Offices
item.description: Many businesses need multiple locations in a region to stay close to their customers. Connecting these branches seamlessly without breaking the bank is a common challenge. Thankfully, two high-performance networking technologies, Metro Ethernet and MPLS Networks, offer affordable solutions that weren’t available even a decade ago. Carrier Ethernet takes the local networking capabilities of Ethernet and extends them across entire cities. This means easy connection and efficient transmission without needing protocol conversions.

item.title: Business Phone Line Options
item.description: By: John Shepler Every business, regardless of size, requires at least one telephone line. While phone lines may seem straightforward, you might have more choices than you realize. Are you confident that your business has the most suitable phone line? Plain Old Telephone Service The traditional analog phone line, known as POTS (Plain Old Telephone Service), is a basic and familiar option. POTS lines are simple, consisting of a single twisted copper pair connecting a standard RJ-11 phone jack on your wall directly to the telephone company’s central office.

item.title: Ethernet over TDM
What is an Ethernet Connection?
item.description: When we consider connecting to the wider world, traditional telecom services like POTS, PRI, T1, DS3, and OCx SONET often come to mind. However, Carrier Ethernet, a newer technology that extends Ethernet from the LAN to the WAN, is worth examining. Extending an Ethernet connection from a building or campus to a distant location might seem strange considering traditional telecom’s long-standing dominance. However, the landscape is changing with new providers entering the market, unburdened by legacy telco standards.

item.title: Why Fiber Optic Metro Ethernet Makes So Much Sense
item.description: By: John Shepler When it comes to connecting your business locations, having the right network setup is crucial. While multiple options exist, Metro Ethernet networks offer unique advantages for optimal performance. Firstly, they maintain the Ethernet protocol throughout your network, unlike other options that require conversions. Secondly, Metro Ethernet networks, especially those based on fiber optics, offer cost advantages compared to alternatives.

item.title: Latest Evidence Of An Ethernet Juggernaut
item.description: A powerful force is transforming the telecommunications industry, shifting it from traditional telegraphy and telephony to a digital packet-based system. This revolution, driven by Ethernet technology, is swiftly changing how our communication networks operate. This shift towards Ethernet in metropolitan and long-distance networks highlights the dominance of digital networks, especially local area networks (LANs), in communication. While voice calls once dominated global traffic, data and video now reign supreme. Video, in particular, is driving the expansion of content delivery networks (CDNs) to handle high-definition content efficiently.

item.title: FastE Fiber as MetroE for Business Ethernet Service
item.description: As businesses increasingly rely on data, the need for high-speed data transfer is becoming crucial. item.title: Why Your Telecom Lines Should Be Switched Ethernet
item.description: By: John Shepler A significant shift is occurring in the telecom industry as traditional circuit-switched networks are being replaced with packet-switched networks. However, some organizations are hesitant to move on from their reliable T1 lines and SONET fiber optic services. This begs the questions: why should they consider transitioning, and to what?

item.title: From LAN to MAN to WAN
item.description: The world is currently experiencing a revolution in network technology. While computer networks have historically relied on various communication protocols, some adapted from the telephone industry, there’s a growing trend towards adopting IP as a universal networking standard. This shift towards IP encompasses all network types, from local area networks (LANs) to metropolitan area networks (MANs) and wide area networks (WANs). This standardization trend originated in LANs. Today, most LANs utilize Ethernet network interfaces due to economies of scale rather than inherent superiority.

item.title: IP T1 Line Service
item.description: T1 lines have been around for a long time, initially used by phone companies to carry multiple calls between their facilities. Eventually, businesses adopted them for their phone systems. When the Internet became widespread, T1 lines were adapted to serve as dedicated internet connections. This might seem odd given their history, but in today’s internet-centric world, T1 lines can indeed function as IP connections. ](http://www.ethernetovercopper.co/) While T1 technology was originally designed for voice calls, the fundamental principle is that digital data is just a series of ones and zeros.

item.title: What is Metro Ethernet?
item.description: Ethernet is a common standard for local networks. Metro Ethernet expands on this, offering the same functionality over larger distances within a metropolitan area. It’s like regular Ethernet but reaches further. Metro Ethernet feels just like local Ethernet, using the same standard connectors. You can connect two networks in separate locations without needing special equipment. This simplicity is thanks to the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF), which sets standards ensuring compatibility between different providers and devices.

What exactly constitutes a telephone trunk? Essentially, it is a collection of phone lines bundled together. Unlike individual analog lines, which consist of a twisted pair of copper wires, a trunk combines multiple lines.

item.title: Gigabit Ethernet vs SONET
item.description: The increasing use of video and cloud services is pushing business bandwidth requirements to gigabit-per-second speeds, necessitating a shift from copper to fiber optic connections. However, there are two primary types of fiber optic bandwidth: SONET and Gigabit Ethernet. Developed by telephone companies, SONET (Synchronous Optical NETwork) was initially designed for transmitting numerous simultaneous phone calls between switching centers, both domestically and internationally. SDH (Synchronous Digital Hierarchy) is its international counterpart, often referenced together as SONET/SDH.

item.title: What Is Lowering Gigabit Ethernet Bandwidth Pricing?

item.description: While your local area network (LAN) might be operating smoothly, connecting to the broader internet for services like dedicated internet access, direct data transfers, or VoIP calls often requires a different approach. Fortunately, modern T1 providers simplify this process with managed routers. item.description: People often think that Local Area Networks (LANs) and Wide Area Networks (WANs) are entirely different, requiring distinct design approaches. But is that always true? WANs, however, emerged from the telephone industry and initially used circuit switching over telephone lines. This historical difference led to a technological gap between LANs and WANs.
